questions.text: Once an array is created, its size _______.
Which of the following are correct to declare an array of int values?
Which of the following are incorrect?
If you declare an array double[] list = new double[5], the highest index in array list is __________.
How many elements are in array double[] list = new double[5]?

Analyze the following code.

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int[] x = new int[3];
    System.out.println("x[0] is " + x[0]);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because the size of the array wasn't specified when declaring the array.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a runtime error because the array elements are not initialized.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program runs fine and displays x[0] is 0.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program has a runtime error because the array element x[0] is not defined.

questions.text: What is the correct term for numbers[99]?
What is the representation of the third element in an array called a?
Suppose int i = 5, which of the following can be used as an index for array double[] t = new double[100]?
If you declare an array double[] list = {3.4, 2.0, 3.5, 5.5}, list[1] is ________.
Which of the following statements are valid?
How can you initialize an array of two characters to 'a' and 'b'?

choices.label: D
choices.text: char[] charArray = new char[2]; charArray[0] = 'a'; charArray[1] = 'b';

questions.text: Assume int[] t = {1, 2, 3, 4}. What is t.length?

What is the output of the following code?

double[] myList = {1, 5, 5, 5, 5, 1};
double max = myList[0];
int indexOfMax = 0;
for (int i = 1; i < myList.length; i++) {
  if (myList[i] > max) {
    max = myList[i];
    indexOfMax = i;
  }
}
System.out.println(indexOfMax);

Analyze the following code:

public class Test { 
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int[] x = new int[5];
    int i;
    for (i = 0; i < x.length; i++)
      x[i] = i;
    System.out.println(x[i]);
  }
}

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has a runtime error because the last statement in the main method causes ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program has a compile error because i is not defined in the last statement in the main method.

questions.text:
What is the output of the following code?

int[] myList = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6};

for (int i = myList.length - 2; i >= 0; i--) {
  myList[i + 1] = myList[i];
}

for (int e: myList) 
  System.out.print(e + " ");

Analyze the following code:

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    double[] x = {2.5, 3, 4};
    for (double value: x)
      System.out.print(value + " ");
  }
}

choices.label: E
choices.text: The program has a syntax error because value is undefined.

questions.text:
What is output of the following code:

public class Test { 
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int[] x = {120, 200, 16};
    for (int i = x.length - 1; i >= 0; i--)
      System.out.print(x[i] + " ");
  }
}

What is output of the following code:

public class Test { 
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int list[] = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6};

    for (int i = 1; i < list.length; i++)
      list[i] = list[i - 1];
    
    for (int i = 0; i < list.length; i++)
      System.out.print(list[i] + " ");
  }
}

In the following code, what is the output for list2?

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int[] list1 = {1, 2, 3};
    int[] list2 = {1, 2, 3};
    list2 = list1;
    list1[0] = 0; list1[1] = 1; list2[2] = 2;

    for (int i = 0; i < list2.length; i++)
      System.out.print(list2[i] + " ");
  }
}

Analyze the following code:

public class Test { 
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int[] x = {1, 2, 3, 4};
    int[] y = x;

    x = new int[2];

    for (int i = 0; i < y.length; i++)
      System.out.print(y[i] + " ");
  }
}

Analyze the following code:

public class Test { 
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    final int[] x = {1, 2, 3, 4};
    int[] y = x;

    x = new int[2];

    for (int i = 0; i < y.length; i++)
      System.out.print(y[i] + " ");
  }
}

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has a compile error on the statement x = new int[2], because x is final and cannot be changed.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The elements in the array x cannot be changed, because x is final.

questions.text:
Analyze the following code.

int[] list = new int[5];
list = new int[6];

choices.label: A
choices.text: The code has compile errors because the variable list cannot be changed once it is assigned.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The code has runtime errors because the variable list cannot be changed once it is assigned.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The code can compile and run fine. The second line assigns a new array to list.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The code has compile errors because you cannot assign a different size array to list.

questions.text:
Analyze the following code:

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int[] a = new int[4];
    a[1] = 1;
    a = new int[2];
    System.out.println("a[1] is " + a[1]);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because new int[2] is assigned to a.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a runtime error because a[1] is not initialized.

questions.text: The __________ method copies the sourceArray to the targetArray.

In the following code, what is the output for list1?

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int[] list1 = {1, 2, 3};
    int[] list2 = {1, 2, 3};
    list2 = list1;
    list1[0] = 0; list1[1] = 1; list2[2] = 2;

    for (int i = 0; i < list1.length; i++)
      System.out.print(list1[i] + " ");
  }
}

Analyze the following code:

public class Test { 
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int[] x = {1, 2, 3, 4};
    int[] y = x;

    x = new int[2];

    for (int i = 0; i < x.length; i++)
      System.out.print(x[i] + " ");
  }
}

Show the output of the following code:

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int[] x = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
    increase(x);

    int[] y = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
    increase(y[0]);

    System.out.println(x[0] + " " + y[0]);
  }

  public static void increase(int[] x) {
    for (int i = 0; i < x.length; i++)
      x[i]++;
  }

  public static void increase(int y) {
    y++;
  }
}

Analyze the following code:

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int[] oldList = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
    reverse(oldList);
    for (int i = 0; i < oldList.length; i++)
      System.out.print(oldList[i] + " ");
  }

  public static void reverse(int[] list) {
    int[] newList = new int[list.length];

    for (int i = 0; i < list.length; i++)
      newList[i] = list[list.length - 1 - i];

    list = newList;
  }
}

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program displays 1 2 3 4 5 and then raises an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program displays 5 4 3 2 1 and then raises an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

questions.text:
Analyze the following code:

public class Test1 { 
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    xMethod(new double[]{3, 3});
    xMethod(new double[5]);
    xMethod(new double[3]{1, 2, 3});
  }

  public static void xMethod(double[] a) {
    System.out.println(a.length);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because xMethod(new double[]{3, 3}) is incorrect.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a compile error because xMethod(new double[5]) is incorrect.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has a compile error because xMethod(new double[3]{1, 2, 3}) is incorrect.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program has a runtime error because a is null.

questions.text:
What would be the result of attempting to compile and run the following code?

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    double[] x = new double[]{1, 2, 3};
    System.out.println("Value is " + x[1]);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because the syntax new double[]{1, 2, 3} is wrong and it should be replaced by {1, 2, 3}.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a compile error because the syntax new double[]{1, 2, 3} is wrong and it should be replaced by new double[3]{1, 2, 3};

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has a compile error because the syntax new double[]{1, 2, 3} is wrong and it should be replaced by new double[]{1.0, 2.0, 3.0};

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program compiles and runs fine and the output "Value is 1.0" is printed.

choices.label: E
choices.text: The program compiles and runs fine and the output "Value is 2.0" is printed.

questions.text:
Do the following two programs produce the same result?

Program I:
public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int[] list = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
    for (int i = 0; i < list.length; i++)
      System.out.print(list[i] + " ");
  }
}

Program II:
public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int[] oldList = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
    reverse(oldList);
    for (int i = 0; i < oldList.length; i++)
      System.out.print(oldList[i] + " ");
  }

  public static void reverse(int[] list) {
    int[] newList = new int[list.length];

    for (int i = 0; i < list.length; i++)
      newList[i] = list[list.length - 1 - i];

    list = newList;
  }
}
When you pass an array to a method, the method receives __________.

choices.label: B
choices.text: a copy of the first element

questions.text: The JVM stores the array in an area of memory, called _______, which is used for dynamic memory allocation where blocks of memory are allocated and freed in an arbitrary order.
Which of the following is correct?
When you return an array from a method, the method returns __________.

choices.label: B
choices.text: a copy of the first element

What return statement may be used in p()?

choices.label: B

choices.label: C

choices.label: E

choices.label: D
choices.text: String[ ] a = new String [5]; for (int i = 0; i < 5; a[i++] = null);

questions.text:
Analyze the following code:

public class Test {
  public static void main(String argv[]) {
    System.out.println("argv.length is " + argv.length);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because String argv[] is wrong and it should be replaced by String[] args.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a compile error because String argv[] is wrong and it should be replaced by String args[].

choices.label: C
choices.text: If you run this program without passing any arguments, the program would have a runtime error because argv is null.

choices.label: D
choices.text: If you run this program without passing any arguments, the program would display argv.length is 0.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct header of the main method?
